docs.abstract: The Chinese telecom giant, which has been dogged by concerns about its ties to Beijing, dropped its top Washington liaison and other American employees.
docs.snippet: The Chinese telecom giant, which has been dogged by concerns about its ties to Beijing, dropped its top Washington liaison and other American employees.
docs.lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China — In a grand hotel ballroom on Tuesday, Huawei executives laid out a soaring vision for the future. The Chinese electronics giant, already the world’s biggest supplier of the equipment that powers the wireless age, now wants to provide the digital backbone for artificial intelligence, the internet of things and other transformative technologies.

headline.main: Huawei, Failing to Crack U.S. Market, Signals a Change in Tactics

byline.original: By Raymond Zhong and Paul Mozur

docs.abstract: The government in China, long suspicious of internet companies, now sees ambitious titans like Tencent and Alibaba as useful partners.
docs.snippet: The government in China, long suspicious of internet companies, now sees ambitious titans like Tencent and Alibaba as useful partners.
docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — For the last decade or so, China has defied the truism that only free and open societies can innovate. Even as the Communist Party has kept an iron grip on politics and discourse, the country’s technology industry has grown to rival Silicon Valley’s in sophistication and ambition.

headline.main: Tech Giants Feel the Squeeze as Xi Jinping Tightens His Grip
headline.print_headline: Tech Giants in China Feel Strain as Xi Tightens Grip

byline.original: By Raymond Zhong and Paul Mozur

docs.abstract: The company, which was barred from using American components, said it had halted “major operating activities.”
docs.snippet: The company, which was barred from using American components, said it had halted “major operating activities.”
docs.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — As China and the United States go toe-to-toe on trade and maneuver ahead of a historic North Korea meeting next month, an unlikely obstacle has emerged: a second-tier Chinese electronics maker, ZTE.

headline.main: In About-Face on Trade, Trump Vows to Protect ZTE Jobs in China
headline.print_headline: Trump Vows to Revive Chinese Company Crushed by U.S. Penalty

byline.original: By Paul Mozur and Raymond Zhong

docs.abstract: Responding to Mark Zuckerberg’s comments in a Vox interview, civil society advocates said Facebook had no consistent methods for dealing with hate speech in Myanmar.
docs.snippet: Responding to Mark Zuckerberg’s comments in a Vox interview, civil society advocates said Facebook had no consistent methods for dealing with hate speech in Myanmar.
docs.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Civil society groups in Myanmar on Thursday criticized Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, arguing that he mischaracterized his company’s effectiveness at detecting and quashing messages encouraging violence in the country.

headline.main: Groups in Myanmar Fire Back at Zuckerberg
headline.print_headline: Zuckerberg Rebuked for Claiming Facebook Defused Hate Speech in Myanmar

docs.abstract: The social network may be too large to truly quit. Our personal tech columnist answers questions from readers who are contemplating deactivation.
docs.snippet: The social network may be too large to truly quit. Our personal tech columnist answers questions from readers who are contemplating deactivation.
docs.lead_paragraph: In the wake of news that the Facebook data of 50 million people was obtained by Cambridge Analytica, a political data firm, many users are mulling whether it is time to leave the social network. Even a co-founder of WhatsApp, which Facebook bought for $16 billion in 2014, declared that it was time to delete Facebook.

headline.print_headline: Want to #DeleteFacebook? Well, You Can Try

docs.abstract: At no point in the demo were the receptionists on the other end of the calls informed that they were talking to a computer rather than another human.
docs.snippet: At no point in the demo were the receptionists on the other end of the calls informed that they were talking to a computer rather than another human.
docs.lead_paragraph: Each week, Kevin Roose, technology columnist at The New York Times, discusses developments in the tech industry, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.

headline.main: Kevin’s Week in Tech: Are Google’s A.I.-Powered Phone Calls Cool, Creepy, or Both?
headline.print_headline: Critics Say Google’s A.I. Phone Calls Have Everything, Except Ethics

docs.abstract: Artificial intelligence video tools make it relatively easy to put one person’s face on another person’s body with few traces of manipulation. I tried it on myself. What could go wrong?
docs.snippet: Artificial intelligence video tools make it relatively easy to put one person’s face on another person’s body with few traces of manipulation. I tried it on myself. What could go wrong?
docs.lead_paragraph: The scene opened on a room with a red sofa, a potted plant and the kind of bland modern art you’d see on a therapist’s wall.

headline.main: Here Come the Fake Videos, Too
headline.print_headline: It Was Only a Matter of Time: Here Comes an App for Fake Videos

docs.abstract: Here’s one thing you can do today so if your laptop is lost or stolen, your private, personal data doesn’t fall into the wrong hands too.
docs.snippet: Here’s one thing you can do today so if your laptop is lost or stolen, your private, personal data doesn’t fall into the wrong hands too.
docs.lead_paragraph: When your laptop is lost or stolen, you aren’t just out $800 (or more). Your personal information is also accessible to whoever takes it, even if you have a password.

headline.main: The One Thing That Protects a Laptop After It’s Been Stolen
headline.print_headline: Was Your Laptop Stolen? All Is Not Necessarily Lost

docs.abstract: Critics have wondered whether the president’s more violent tweets — including those directed at North Korea — could merit a suspension or ban. Here’s what Twitter has said.
docs.snippet: Critics have wondered whether the president’s more violent tweets — including those directed at North Korea — could merit a suspension or ban. Here’s what Twitter has said.
docs.lead_paragraph: President Trump boasted Tuesday evening that he had a “nuclear button” that is “much bigger” and “more powerful” than North Korea’s, again prompting fears that an errant tweet could lead to a nuclear conflict. (It is worth noting that there is no nuclear button.)

headline.main: Twitter’s Shifting Positions on Trump’s Tweets

byline.original: By Jonah Engel Bromwich and Johanna Barr

docs.abstract: Photographers who want to leave the bulky laptop at home can edit and save images in the uncompressed RAW format right on Apple’s tablet.
docs.snippet: Photographers who want to leave the bulky laptop at home can edit and save images in the uncompressed RAW format right on Apple’s tablet.
docs.lead_paragraph: Q. Can I edit RAW image files from my D.S.L.R. on an iPad Pro? If so, is it possible to save the edited images back to the computer later so I don’t have to take a laptop with me on my trip?

headline.main: Editing RAW Images on an iPad
